We have noticed (p. 18) that the ‘continuone movement' Ι of the voice, as described by Aristoxenus, does not include a gradual change of pitch, if bounded by fixed degrees of pitch. The treatment may be said to be faulty to that extent. In fact, the difference between the two kinds of motion, when analyned‚ turns out to be more a difference of steadiness and unsteadiness in pitch than simply a difference in the manner in which it may change from acute to grave and cicc owed. In κίνησις συνεχής the pitch is nowhere steady and is always varying; in κίνησις διαστηματική it is steady now at this height, now at that, and never varies except by leaps. The sounds which constitute the former are then to be found in the class of sounds commonly styled ‘non-musical‚' those which constitute the latter, in the ‘musical' class.l
